If you think 30p for a Freddo is a bad deal then get ready for this one. 
A price comparison website is predicting our favourite chocolate bars including Twirls, Kit Kats, Mars bars and Crunchies, could cost over a £1 next year. 
The sweet treats have already seen a price rise over the past year, due to the pound’s post-Brexit vote slump, falling production and increased demand world wide for chocolate, The Mirror reports. 
According to mysupermarket.com, the cost of your chocolate bars has shot up by 13% in the last year. Read More Cadbury's Freddo bars price to go up to 30p and chocolate fans are not happy! 
The rise has accelerated since 2016’s EU referendum, where the Leave vote was followed by a slump in Sterling’s value. 
If things stay on track, then we could expect to be handing over at least a pound for a bar in 2018. 
Gilad Simhony, CEO of mySupermarket.co.uk, said: “If this rate continues we could be paying over £1 for a regular bar in 2018.” A Nestle Kit Kat Chunky chocolate bar (Photo: Steve Parsons/PA Wire) 
Increased demand for chocolate in countries like Brazil, China and Russia is also affecting prices, while the world’s biggest cocoa producer, The Ivory Coast, has seen harvests drop in recent years. 
Since June’s EU referendum vote, prices of every day commodities have risen. 
The average price of a 150g Heinz beans tin has jumped by 9%, up to 53p. Read More I Can't Believe It's Not Butter to change it's name - can you believe it? 
Hovis bread prices have risen by an average of 5%, with Kingsmill loaves jumping by 2%. 
The National Association of British and Irish Flour Millers, says British bread wheat now costs 38% more as a result of the weak pound and “supply issues”. Like us on Facebook
